markdownRemark.html:
Score: 87.5

uproxx.com  (WEB - en-US)

A website based in Culver City, California, mainly focused on entertainment and pop culture news, that provides in-depth features and criticism primarily for young men. It calls itself “The Culture of Now.”

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The site is owned by privately held Uproxx Media Group, previously called Woven Digital, a video-focused publisher that owns other sites including HitFix, Dime, and BroBible. The sites carry advertising.

Content

Besides breaking news of interest to its predominantly male millennial audience, the home page has tabs for entertainment, music, sports, life/discovery and video/podcasts.

The top news link shares content from theintercept.com,  which is focused on national security. Sports coverage includes stories about pro wrestling. Entertainment coverage offers a broad range of TV and movies; and hip-hop and indie rock get most of the music attention. Shorter articles are usually trending news stories, while longer pieces strive to offer a big-picture, distinctive voice.

Credibility

Stories typically have multiple, named sources, and headlines capture their  articles’ content. Photos complement stories; photo credits are given, but many are supplied by the publicity departments of TV shows or movie studios that illustrate stories on the site. 

A headline such as “ ‘Solo’ Is Officially The Least Interesting ‘Star Wars’ Movie To Talk About” demonstrates a critical eye. Other typical headlines: “The Dos and Don’ts of Dining at a Restaurant Without Being a Jerk” and “From ‘Dark Fantasy’ to ‘Ye’: Kanye West’s Decade-Long Slide from Greatness to Mediocrity.”

No corrections appeared on the site. A NewsGuard email seeking information on its corrections policy wasn’t returned.

Transparency

Stories have bylines, which supply a mini-biography of the writer. The masthead gives emails and Twitter handles for ranking editors, staffers and the studio and leadership team, as well as a street address.

History

Jarret Myer and Brian Brater, co-founders of the hip-hop Rawkus Records label, launched the site in 2008.

Written by:
Douglas Rowe

Edited by:
Amy Westfeldt Joyce Purnick
